title: 107_s3096
content: The Act is titled the "Ballistics, Law Assistance, and Safety Technology Act" or the "BLAST Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Ballistics, Law Assistance, and Safety Technology Act" aims to increase public safety by assisting law enforcement in solving gun-related crimes through ballistics technology. It requires ballistics testing of new firearms for sale and those in custody of Federal agencies to aid in identifying firearms used in crimes. Additionally, it adds ballistics testing to existing firearms enforcement programs. The definition of ballistics is a comparative analysis of fired bullets and cartridge casings to identify the firearm used. The Act also includes provisions for test firing and automated storage of ballistics records. Amendment to Section 923 of title 18, United States Code requires licensed manufacturers or importers to test fire firearms, prepare ballistics images, and store records in a computerized database. Licensed manufacturers or importers must test fire firearms, prepare ballistics images, and store records in a computerized database as required by an amendment to Section 923 of title 18, United States Code. This does not create civil liability except for civil penalties. The Attorney General and the Secretary will assist firearm manufacturers and importers in complying with these requirements. The Attorney General and the Secretary will assist firearm manufacturers and importers in complying with requirements such as acquiring ballistics equipment, hiring personnel for database maintenance, and conducting research and evaluation. The Attorney General and the Secretary will assist manufacturers and importers in developing and maintaining a database of ballistics images, providing education on ballistics, coordinating with law enforcement agencies, and taking necessary steps to make ballistics testing effective. The Attorney General and the Secretary will establish a computer system for accessing ballistics records and encourage training for examiners to make ballistics testing effective. The Attorney General and the Secretary will establish a computer system for accessing ballistics records and encourage training for examiners. They will submit an annual report to Congress on the impact of this section, including the number of investigations and prosecutions utilizing ballistics records. The report will include the number of criminal investigations and prosecutions using ballistics records, the accessibility of these records across jurisdictions, and a statistical evaluation of test programs conducted under the Ballistics, Law Assistance, and State Technology Act. Authorized funding of $20,000,000 for fiscal years 2001 through 2004 to the Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury for implementing ballistics equipment, testing sites, personnel salaries, and research. The amendment authorizes funding for ballistics equipment, testing sites, personnel salaries, and research. Mandatory ballistics testing of firearms by the Secretary and Attorney General is required. Effective date of the amendment is determined by the Attorney General and Secretary. The amendment made by subsection (a) will take effect once the Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury certify the interoperability of ballistics systems for mandatory testing of new firearms. The Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury have interoperable ballistics systems for mandatory testing of new firearms. Section 923(m)(1) of title 18, United States Code, will take effect 5 years after the enactment of this Act, while section 923(m)(6) will be effective on the date of enactment. SEC. 5. PRIVACY RIGHTS OF LAW ABIDING CITIZENS. Ballistics information of individual guns may not be used for prosecutorial purposes unless law enforcement has reasonable belief of a crime and that the information would assist in the investigation.
